summary.text: Object containing the initial payload.
Object containing responses of Invoke handlers on steps flagged with saveResponse.
Object containing responses of Compensate handlers on steps flagged with saveResponse.
The metadata of the transaction.
The initial payload data to begin a transation.
Object gathering responses of all steps flagged with saveResponse.
DistributedTransaction represents a distributed transaction, which is a transaction that is composed of multiple steps that are executed in a specific order.
Defines the structure and behavior of a single step within a transaction workflow.
Defines the next step(s) to execute after this step. Can be a single step or an array of steps.

A unique identifier for the transaction step.
This is set automatically when declaring a workflow with "createWorkflow"

Specifies the action to be performed in this step.
"name" is an alias for action when creating a workflow with "createWorkflow".

Indicates whether the workflow should continue even if there is a permanent failure in this step.
In case it is set to true, the the current step will be marked as TransactionStepState.PERMANENT_FAILURE and the next steps will be executed.

Indicates whether the workflow should skip all subsequent steps in case of a permanent failure in this step.
In case it is set to true, the next steps of the workflow will not be executed and their status will be marked as TransactionStepState.SKIPPED_FAILURE.
In case it is a string, the next steps until the step name provided will be skipped and the workflow will be resumed from the step provided.
If true, no compensation action will be triggered for this step in case of a failure.

The maximum number of times this step should be retried in case of temporary failures.
The default is 0 (no retries).

The interval (in seconds) between retry attempts after a temporary failure.
The default is to retry immediately.
The interval (in seconds) to retry a step even if its status is "TransactionStepStatus.WAITING".

The maximum amount of time (in seconds) to wait for this step to complete.
This is NOT an execution timeout, the step will always be executed and wait for its response.
If the response is not received within the timeout set, it will be marked as "TransactionStepStatus.TIMEOUT" and the workflow will be reverted as soon as it receives the response.

If true, the step is executed asynchronously. This means that the workflow will not wait for the response of this step.
Async steps require to have their responses set using "setStepSuccess" or "setStepFailure", unless it is combined with "backgroundExecution: true".
If combined with a timeout, and any response is not set within that interval, the step will be marked as "TransactionStepStatus.TIMEOUT" and the workflow will be reverted immediately.
It flags where the step contains a sub transaction inside itself.

It applies to "async" steps only, allowing them to run in the background and automatically complete without external intervention.
It is ideal for time-consuming tasks that will be complete after the execution, contrasting with standard "async" operations that require a response to be set in a later stage.
If true, the compensation function for this step is executed asynchronously. Which means, the response has to be set using "setStepSuccess" or "setStepFailure".
If true, the workflow will not wait for their sibling steps to complete before moving to the next step.

If true, the response of this step will be stored.
Default is true.

TransactionOrchestrator is responsible for managing and executing distributed transactions.
It is based on a single transaction definition, which is used to execute all the transaction steps
Trace workflow transaction for instrumentation
Trace workflow steps for instrumentation
Finalize the transaction when all steps are complete
Prepare a step for execution by setting state and incrementing attempts
Create the payload for a step execution
Prepare handler arguments for step execution
Create the step execution promise with optional tracing
Execute a synchronous step and handle its result
Execute an asynchronous step and handle its result
Check if step or transaction has expired and handle timeouts
Handle successful step completion
Handle step failure
Start a new transaction or resume a transaction that has been previously started
The transaction to resume
Cancel and revert a transaction compensating all its executed steps. It can be an ongoing transaction or a completed one
The transaction to be reverted
Create a new transaction
Returns an existing transaction
unique identifier of the transaction
function to handle action of the transaction
Skip the execution of a specific transaction and step
Register a step success for a specific transaction and step
Register a step failure for a specific transaction and step
TransactionStep

content.text: A class representing a single step in a transaction flow
id - The id of the step
depth - The depth of the step in the flow
definition - The definition of the step
invoke - The current state and status of the invoke action of the step
compensate - The current state and status of the compensate action of the step
attempts - The number of attempts made to execute the step
failures - The number of failures encountered while executing the step
lastAttempt - The timestamp of the last attempt made to execute the step
hasScheduledRetry - A flag indicating if a retry has been scheduled
retryRescheduledAt - The timestamp of the last retry scheduled
next - The ids of the next steps in the flow
saveResponse - A flag indicating if the response of a step should be shared in the transaction context and available to subsequent steps - default is true

summary.text: Defines the structure and behavior of a single step within a transaction workflow.

A unique identifier for the transaction step.
This is set automatically when declaring a workflow with "createWorkflow"

Specifies the action to be performed in this step.
"name" is an alias for action when creating a workflow with "createWorkflow".

Indicates whether the workflow should continue even if there is a permanent failure in this step.
In case it is set to true, the the current step will be marked as TransactionStepState.PERMANENT_FAILURE and the next steps will be executed.

Indicates whether the workflow should skip all subsequent steps in case of a permanent failure in this step.
In case it is set to true, the next steps of the workflow will not be executed and their status will be marked as TransactionStepState.SKIPPED_FAILURE.
In case it is a string, the next steps until the step name provided will be skipped and the workflow will be resumed from the step provided.
If true, no compensation action will be triggered for this step in case of a failure.

The maximum number of times this step should be retried in case of temporary failures.
The default is 0 (no retries).

The interval (in seconds) between retry attempts after a temporary failure.
The default is to retry immediately.
The interval (in seconds) to retry a step even if its status is "TransactionStepStatus.WAITING".

The maximum amount of time (in seconds) to wait for this step to complete.
This is NOT an execution timeout, the step will always be executed and wait for its response.
If the response is not received within the timeout set, it will be marked as "TransactionStepStatus.TIMEOUT" and the workflow will be reverted as soon as it receives the response.

If true, the step is executed asynchronously. This means that the workflow will not wait for the response of this step.
Async steps require to have their responses set using "setStepSuccess" or "setStepFailure", unless it is combined with "backgroundExecution: true".
If combined with a timeout, and any response is not set within that interval, the step will be marked as "TransactionStepStatus.TIMEOUT" and the workflow will be reverted immediately.
It flags where the step contains a sub transaction inside itself.

It applies to "async" steps only, allowing them to run in the background and automatically complete without external intervention.
It is ideal for time-consuming tasks that will be complete after the execution, contrasting with standard "async" operations that require a response to be set in a later stage.
If true, the compensation function for this step is executed asynchronously. Which means, the response has to be set using "setStepSuccess" or "setStepFailure".
If true, the workflow will not wait for their sibling steps to complete before moving to the next step.

If true, the response of this step will be stored.
Default is true.
Defines the next step(s) to execute after this step. Can be a single step or an array of steps.
Defines the options for a transaction model, which are applicable to the entire workflow.
The global timeout for the entire transaction workflow (in seconds).

If true, the state of the transaction will be persisted.

Learn more in [this documentation](https://docs.medusajs.com/learn/fundamentals/workflows/store-executions).

The number of seconds that the workflow execution should be stored in the database.

Learn more in [this documentation](https://docs.medusajs.com/learn/fundamentals/workflows/store-executions).
If true, the execution details of each step will be stored.

content.text: no longer needed.

summary.text: If true, the workflow will use the transaction ID as the key to ensure only-once execution

Defines the workflow as a scheduled workflow that executes based on the cron configuration passed.
The value can either by a cron expression string, or an object that also allows to define the concurrency behavior.

Setting whether to allow concurrent executions (eg. if the previous execution is still running, should the new one be allowed to run or not)
By default concurrent executions are not allowed.
Optionally limit the number of executions for the scheduled workflow. If not set, the workflow will run indefinitely.
The cron expression to schedule the workflow execution.
The interval (in ms) to schedule the workflow execution.

The following interface acts as a bucket that other modules or the
utils package can fill using declaration merging

The Medusa Container extends [Awilix](https://github.com/jeffijoe/awilix) to
provide dependency injection functionalities.

The ID of the event's group. Grouped events are useful when you have distributed transactions
where you need to explicitly group, release and clear events upon lifecycle events of a transaction.

When set, you must release the grouped events using the Event Module's
`releaseGroupedEvents`
method to emit the events.
The event's name.

content.text:
```ts
user.created
```

only used in exceptional cases - relying on the shared contrainer breaks encapsulation

`TManager`

, which is a typed parameter passed to the context to specify the type of the
`manager`

`REPEATABLE READ`
, or
`SERIALIZABLE`

preventReleaseEvents

Representation of a hook definition.
Returns the result of the hook

By prefixing a key with a space, we remove it from the
intellisense of TypeScript. This is needed because
input is not set at runtime. It is a type-only
property to infer input data type of a hook

Expose a hook in your workflow where you can inject custom functionality as a step function.

A handler hook can later be registered to consume the hook and perform custom functionality.

Learn more in [this documentation](https://docs.medusajs.com/learn/fundamentals/workflows/workflow-hooks).

content.text: A workflow hook.

summary.text: The hook's name. This is used when the hook handler is registered to consume the workflow.
The input to pass to the hook handler.
The type of invocation function passed to a step.
The type of the input that the function expects.
The type of the output that the function returns.
The type of the input that the compensation function expects.

content.text: The expected output based on the type parameter
`TOutput`

summary.text: The type of compensation function passed to a step.
The type of the argument passed to the compensation function. If not specified, then it will be the same type as the invocation function's output.

content.text: There's no expected type to be returned by the compensation function.

summary.text: This function creates a
StepFunction
that can be used as a step in a workflow constructed by the
createWorkflow
function.

content.text: A step function to be used in a workflow.

summary.text: The type of the expected input parameter to the invocation function.
The type of the expected output parameter of the invocation function.
The type of the expected input parameter to the compensation function.
The name of the step or its configuration.
An invocation function that will be executed when the workflow is executed. The function must return an instance of
StepResponse
. The constructor of
StepResponse
accepts the output of the step as a first argument, and optionally as a second argument the data to be passed to the compensation function as a parameter.

A compensation function that's executed if an error occurs in the workflow. It's used to roll-back actions when errors occur.
It accepts as a parameter the second argument passed to the constructor of the
StepResponse

instance returned by the invocation function. If the
invocation function doesn't pass the second argument to
`StepResponse`

constructor, the compensation function receives the first argument
passed to the
`StepResponse`
constructor instead.

This function creates a workflow with the provided name and a constructor function.
The constructor function builds the workflow from steps created by the
createStep

function.
The returned workflow is an exported workflow of type
ReturnWorkflow

, meaning it's not executed right away. To execute it,
invoke the exported workflow, then run its
`run`
method.

content.text: The created workflow. You can later execute the workflow by invoking it, then using its
`run`
method.

summary.text: The type of the input passed to the composer function.
The type of the output returned by the composer function.
The type of hooks defined in the workflow.
The name of the workflow or its configuration.
The constructor function that is executed when the
`run`
method in
ReturnWorkflow

is used.
The function can't be an arrow function or an asynchronus function. It also can't directly manipulate data.
You'll have to use the
transform
function if you need to directly manipulate data.
This class is used to create the response returned by a step. A step return its data by returning an instance of
`StepResponse`
The constructor of the StepResponse
The type of the output of the step.
The type of the compensation input. If the step doesn't specify any compensation input, then the type of
`TCompensateInput`

is the same
as that of
`TOutput`
The output of the step.
The input to be passed as a parameter to the step's compensation function. If not provided, the
`output`
will be provided instead.
Creates a StepResponse that indicates that the step has failed and the retry mechanism should not kick in anymore.
An optional message to be logged.
The type of the output of the step.
The type of the compensation input. If the step doesn't specify any compensation input, then the type of
`TCompensateInput`

is the same
as that of

Workflow response class encapsulates the return value of a workflow
This function is used to run multiple steps in parallel. The result of each step will be returned as part of the result array.

content.text: The step results. The results are ordered in the array by the order they're passed in the function's parameter.

summary.text: The type of the expected result.

This function transforms the output of other utility functions.

For example, if you're using the value(s) of some step(s) as an input to a later step. As you can't directly manipulate data in the  workflow constructor function passed to
createWorkflow

,
the
`transform`

function provides access to the runtime value of the step(s) output so that you can manipulate them.

Another example is if you're using the runtime value of some step(s) as the output of a workflow.

If you're also retrieving the output of a hook and want to check if its value is set, you must use a workflow to get the runtime value of that hook.

content.text: There's no expected value to be returned by the
`transform`
function.

`values`

Adding a space hides the method from the autocomplete
An exported workflow, which is the type of a workflow constructed by the
createWorkflow

function. The exported workflow can be invoked to create
an executable workflow, optionally within a specified container. So, to execute the workflow, you must invoke the exported workflow, then run the
`run`
method of the exported workflow.

content.text: To execute a workflow:

To specify the container of the workflow, you can pass it as an argument to the call of the exported workflow. This is necessary when executing the workflow
within a Medusa resource such as an API Route or a Subscriber.

For example:

summary.text:
This method executes the workflow as a step. Useful when running a workflow within another.

Learn more in [this documentation](https://docs.medusajs.com/learn/fundamentals/workflows/execute-another-workflow).

content.text: The workflow's result

summary.text: The workflow's input.
This method executes a workflow.

content.text: Details of the workflow's execution, including its result.

summary.text: The options to execute the workflow.

This method sets the workflow's configurations.

The workflow's exposed hooks, used to register a handler to consume the hook.

Learn more in [this documentation](https://docs.medusajs.com/learn/fundamentals/workflows/workflow-hooks#how-to-consume-a-hook).

type WorkflowInputData = UnwrapWorkflowInputDataType<typeof myWorkflow>
